entry.title: Yinyoo KBEAR Storm in-Ear Monitors
entry.content:
Overview

The KBEAR Storm is a budget-priced single dynamic driver (1DD) in-ear monitor (IEM) from Yinyoo, designed with the aim of bringing high-fidelity sound to musicians, performers, and everyday listeners. At just ¬£17.99, it promises impressive specs for the price ‚Äî including a detachable silver-plated cable, a 10mm magnetic driver, and multiple eartip options.

We were intrigued. Unfortunately, when it comes to bass ‚Äî the one thing that really matters for this site ‚Äî the KBEAR Storm fails hard.

Pros

  • Good Build Quality: The plastic housings feel well-made and solid, especially at this price point.
  • Comfortable Fit: Lightweight and ergonomically shaped; they stay put during long sessions without fatigue.
  • Attractive Design: Available in several colours with a sleek, modern look.
  • Decent Accessories: Comes with multiple eartips (6 pairs in 3 sizes), which helps with fit and isolation.
  • Quiet Cable: The over-ear cable doesn‚Äôt transmit rubbing noise, and it‚Äôs removable, allowing for upgrades.

Cons

  • Lack of Bass Response: The biggest issue. The low end is practically absent, and even EQ boosting doesn‚Äôt help much.
  • Tinny Sound: Without low-end support, the overall sound signature leans heavily toward thin and brittle.

The Bass Test

As a bass-centric review site, we‚Äôre always evaluating IEMs by how well they handle low frequencies ‚Äî both for listening and monitoring live bass. The KBEAR Storm, despite manufacturer claims of ‚Äúpowerful and affecting bass,‚Äù simply does not deliver.

No matter the source ‚Äî phone, DAC/amp, or EQ tweaks ‚Äî the low end remained thin and lifeless. Boosting 60‚Äì100 Hz did very little. Even 500 Hz boosts to recover warmth didn‚Äôt add punch. For bass players or fans of bass-heavy music, this makes the KBEAR Storm unusable.

Verdict

If you‚Äôre on a tight budget, mainly listening to podcasts, or using a Samsung phone with Dolby Atmos and you don‚Äôt care about bass, the KBEAR Storm might be a comfortable and affordable entry-level IEM.

But if you‚Äôre a bass player, a music producer, or just a fan of heavy low-end, these are not for you.

Final Rating

üéß Comfort & Fit: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ

üé® Build & Aesthetics: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ

üí∞ Value for Money: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ

üéµ Sound (General): ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ

üé∏ Bass Performance: ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ (unusable for bass monitoring)

entry.title: Sterling by Music Man S.U.B. Sting Ray 4
entry.content:
Sterling by Music Man S.U.B. Ray4 Review ‚Äì The Budget Stingray That Missed the Mark

Let‚Äôs get one thing out of the way: I‚Äôve always wanted a Stingray. That big, bold Music Man tone, the iconic look, and that unmistakable 3+1 headstock have been calling my name for years. So when I spotted the Sterling by Music Man S.U.B. Ray4, I figured this might finally scratch the itch‚Äîwithout emptying the wallet.

S.U.B., in case you didn‚Äôt know, stands for ‚ÄúSports Utility Bass‚Äù‚Äîand this Indonesian-made model is the most affordable entry into the Stingray world. It‚Äôs got the vibe, the looks (mostly), and the layout. But unfortunately, it didn‚Äôt quite deliver in the ways that matter most.

First Impressions

Out of the box, the Vintage Cream finish was‚Ä¶ not quite what I expected. Online it looked classy and understated, but in person it leaned a bit more pink‚Äîkind of a ‚Äúskin tone‚Äù shade that didn‚Äôt feel as bold or confident as I hoped. That‚Äôs purely subjective, of course, but it did leave me a little underwhelmed at first glance.

That said, it still has the classic Stingray shape, the 3+1 headstock, and a nice slim 38mm nut width that makes it comfortable in the hand.

Build & Hardware

Now, this is where things started to wobble‚Äîliterally. While tuning up for the first time, two of the tuners slipped as I tightened them. That‚Äôs not something you want to experience on a brand-new bass, no matter the price.

The body is made of basswood, paired with a maple neck and a jatoba fretboard. It‚Äôs a familiar recipe for budget instruments, and overall the construction is okay. Nothing alarming‚Äîaside from the tuners‚Äîbut nothing exceptional either.

Tone & Electronics

The S.U.B. Ray4 comes equipped with a single H-1 ceramic humbucker and active 2-band EQ. On paper, that should give you plenty of tonal flexibility and the aggressive Stingray bite we all know and love.

In practice? It just felt a little flat. The tone lacked dynamics, and even with some EQ tweaking, I couldn‚Äôt quite dial in the kind of presence I was after. The active electronics gave it volume and brightness, but not much character. It felt like the essence of the Stingray was only half there‚Äîlike a photocopy of a painting.

Verdict: Good, But Not Great

Look, this isn‚Äôt a bad bass. It‚Äôs a decent entry point if you want to get close to the Stingray aesthetic and layout without the cost. But for me, it didn‚Äôt quite deliver where it mattered. Between the underwhelming tone, the slightly off colour, and the tuner issues, I just couldn‚Äôt justify keeping it.

Especially when you consider that my Harley Benton MB-4 SBK, which costs about a third of the price, feels about the same level of build quality and sounds better to my ears.

The Bottom Line

‚úÖ Pros:

  • Classic Stingray shape and layout
  • Comfortable neck with a slim nut width
  • Active EQ offers tonal options
  • That 3+1 headstock still looks cool

‚ùå Cons:

  • Flat, uninspiring tone
  • Colour looked different in person
  • Tuner reliability was questionable
  • Doesn‚Äôt feel like good value compared to other options

If you‚Äôre desperate for a Stingray and you‚Äôre on a tight budget, the S.U.B. Ray4 might scratch the itch‚Äîjust don‚Äôt expect fireworks. Personally, I think there are better-value alternatives out there.

Final verdict? Close, but no cigar.

entry.title: Harley Benton MB-4 SBK
entry.content:
Why I Bought the Harley Benton MB-4 SBK‚Äîand Why I‚Äôm Keeping It

After sending back a Sterling by Music Man Stingray Ray S.U.B 4, I found myself on the hunt for a bass that wouldn‚Äôt break the bank but still delivered in all the ways that matter: sound, build, feel, and style. Enter the Harley Benton MB-4 SBK‚Äîa budget-friendly beast that surprised me in all the best ways.

First Impressions

Out of the box, the MB-4 SBK oozes attitude. Its matte black finish, black hardware, and matching headstock give it a stealthy, modern look. It feels solid, tipping the scales at around 4 kg, with a full 34-inch scale and a bolt-on maple neck topped with a roseacer fretboard. The neck has a comfy D-profile and a nice low action, making it easy to zip around the 21 frets.

The Sound

Let‚Äôs cut to the chase: it sounds fantastic‚Äîespecially for the price. The Humbucker pickup with passive electronics delivers that scooped sound you would expect from a Stingray-style bass. It does have versatility with the tone control you can get some mellow sounds, but it really shines when you crank the treble.

But be warned‚Äîthe output is hot. Like, really hot. So hot, in fact, that it overloads my Digitech Drop pedal. If you‚Äôre running into pedals or an interface, you might want to check your gain staging.

Playability & Build

This thing plays beautifully. The fretwork is clean, the finish is flawless, and the build quality feels far above what you‚Äôd expect at this price. The body is made from poplar, which is lightweight but still gives a nice, balanced tone. The die-cast bridge is solid and keeps things nicely anchored.

The Downsides

It‚Äôs not perfect, of course. A few small issues stood out:

  • The volume knobs rubbed against the control plate slightly and needed to be lifted a bit to stop catching.
  • The tuners feel cheap, and there‚Äôs a little play when you turn them‚Äîbut they do hold tuning well, so it‚Äôs more of a feel thing than a functional problem.
  • I‚Äôm not in love with the two volume knob setup. I‚Äôd personally prefer a single volume control and a standard tone knob, rather than juggling two knobs to blend the coils.
  • The matte finish will show fingerprints and smudges, and over time will lose its sheen.

Final Thoughts

All things considered, the Harley Benton MB-4 SBK punches way above its weight. For the price, you‚Äôre getting:

‚úÖ Excellent sound
‚úÖ Impressive build quality
‚úÖ Stealth aesthetics
‚úÖ Comfortable playability
‚úÖ Remarkable value for money
‚úÖ Passive electronics (no batteries needed!)

If you‚Äôre okay with a couple of minor quirks‚Äîand maybe swapping out the tuners down the line‚Äîyou‚Äôll find a lot to love here. Whether you‚Äôre just starting out or need a solid backup bass, the MB-4 SBK is a serious contender.

Would I buy it again? Absolutely.

Harley Benton MB-4 SBK product page

Back to Black

One thing that bothered me was the tort pickguard. It just didn‚Äôt match the sleek black aesthetic of the rest of the instrument.

The Musically pickguard on Amazon fitted with a small amount of trimming at the neck pocket, and it‚Äôs 9 holes didn‚Äôt quite line up with the original 7, but it works well enough.

BTW - You can see the fingerprints and dust that the matte finish picks up :¬¨)
